characters: INT. CORINTH COFFEE SHOP, YORK AVENUE, DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patch of water. PULL BACK TO REVEAL more water.  BACK FARTHER TO REVEAL an expanse of river, up the bank to massive lawn running up to a great, classic Hudson River manor house; the country estate of William Parrish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE THROUGH French doors that lead from a wide terrace i an expansive living room, DOWN wide corridors lined with Bierstadt and Cole paintings, the Hudson River School, mi and trees and small boats and distant humans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE THROUGH the doorway to reveal a master bedroom furni ed with exquisite simplicity, revelatory of its sleeping occupant, WILLIAM PARRISH, 64, a warm but commanding face man of maturity yet who exudes a glow of enthusiasm. Although asleep, there is an uncommon restlessness to him Parrish grips his upper arm as if in pain.  Now the sever of the pain wakes him, he squeezes his arm.  The wind com up, through the wind a VOICE is heard distantly, or is it wind itself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yes. Parrish blinks, has he heard something, has he not, he is not sure, he releases his arm, his grimace of pain fades, the discomfort seems momentarily to have subsided. He rises now, crosses to the bathroom.  As he pees, a bre outside the window, the wind again, but then the Voice co up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... It is unmistakably a Voice, it is not the wind, Parrish h heard something, he looks around, but no one is there.  H can't finish peeing, turns back to his bedroom.  All bewe ered, Parrish looks around once more, climbs back into be trying to trace the source of what he has heard or hasn't heard; he is not sure. He pulls the covers up now, not a SOUND, tries to close h eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Parrish sits up again, frightened, but still there is no there, he seems fraught with indecision, should he get up should he not, what is happening?  He looks out: absolute stillness and silence, CRICKETS chirp down by the river, light FLICKERS from a shadboat, Parrish closes his eyes b then they flutter open, he glances up at the ceiling and finally, exhausted, falls back asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great lawn infested with workmen, planting stakes, un rolling a huge canvas tent, gardeners fashioning topiary adding landscaping of their own, crews setting up platfor speakers, lights.  Ubiquitous is ALLISON, 35, Parrish's older daughter, foremen competing for her attention and s relishing every moment. A Painter approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big tent, Miss Allison --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paint is rust and moss green. Medieval colors -- Daddy's like an old knight. A Florist stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The head table --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flowers, ma'am--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freesia, freesia, everywhere.  Daddy loves freesia -- and you, over there, lights.  Not too bright.  I'm looking for a saffron glow -- sort of tea- dance twenties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish, groomed for the day, trots down the stairs, obse ing the activity outside through the windows.  He checks watch, strides down the hall, encounters MAY, 50, a famil retainer who is opening the doors to the terrace as Parri passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of all this, May?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be beautiful.  And Miss Allison says the President may come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the President's got better things to do than come to my birthday party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Parrish grins, continues on, is intercepted by Allison wh on catching sight of him, bounces in from the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Allison --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much more.  Big day in the big city.  What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fireworks.  Update -- we're con- structing the number '65' on the barge, archers from the State College at New Paltz will shoot flaming arrows at it, when it catches fire it will give us the effect of a Viking funeral with none of the morbidity... The Hudson River Authority says, for you, they'll make a special dispensation - of course there'll be an overtime bill for the Poughkeepsie Fire Dept...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison, I trust you.  This is your thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's your birthday. Parrish smiles complaisantly, they continue on into a bre fast room where SUSAN, 30, Parrish's younger daughter, is grazing at a table laden with cereals and fruits and coff

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Allison, you're 'honey'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew called from the AStar, they're still two minutes away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew's aboard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanted to ride back down with you. Now sit and relax, get some- thing in that flat tummy of yours -- But Parrish only pours coffee. SUSAN (cont'd) (to Allison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got patients waiting, I've got three hysterical chefs, one loves truffles, the other hates truffles, the third one doesn't know what truffles are.  I'd better drive down. Parrish gazes at the going-on outside which are increasin in intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconsciously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate parties --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, Daddy, you'll see, you're going to love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it enough to be on this earth sixty-five years without having to be reminded of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Allison goes, Susan observes Parrish fidgeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you relax?  I know it is a big deal day --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does Drew tell you everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I guess so. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like to interfere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Then don't. The helicopter CHOPS in overhead. SUSAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Here comes our boy now -- Shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BUTLER and May carry the overnight bags for the family led by Parrish, they hurry towards the helicopter.  En ro they pass QUINCE, 38, Allison's husband, who is perched a portable bar with AMBROSE, the head caterer, tasting wine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...This shit's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- The late harvest Riesling, Mr. Quince, a possibility for dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to another bottle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinot Grigio.  We're considering it for the appetizer. Ambrose takes a sip, swishes the wine in his mouth, spits in a bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well sir, it's 9:30 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9:30's almost 10:30.  Where I come from, the sun's over the yardarm, m'boy, and the cocktail lamp is lit. Quince drains his wine, presents it for a refill, when he hailed by Allison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quince!  Everybody's waiting! Quince downs this glass too, runs for the helicopter as DREW, 34, a young man going places, emerges from it, approaches Parrish and Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Drew kisses her, over her shoulder he glances at Parrish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Drew.  Thanks for coming out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a big day.  Wanted to line up a few ducks before kickoff. Any thoughts?  Last minute refine- ments or variations?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Thoughts'?  Not a one -- but I did hear a voice last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Yes'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Yes' to the deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, who knows?  You know how voices are.  Let's go. Quince comes running up now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Bill --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Quince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you doing--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing great.  You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am, this is it.  B Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that, Quince?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bontecou Day.  Going to close with Big John -- Look at you, Bill, all cool as a cat and over at Bontecou's, I'll bet he's shitting in his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Quince)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  All aboard - New York, New York!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember everybody, tonight, dinner in the city at Daddy's.  You too, Drew.  We've still got some loose ends --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my birthday again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're only six-five once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.  Now could we go?  Let's get this day started. Drew ushers everybody on, first Parrish, then Susan and Quince, Drew the last to climb on, shuts the door behind As Allison hurries away from the whirling rotors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The configuration of seats has Drew beside Parrish, in fr of them Quince and Susan opposite each other in single se Just as Drew removes color-coded folders from his attache case and spreads them out for Parrish on his tray table, pilot waves to Drew, indicating 'phone call'.  Drew gets and heads for the cockpit, Parrish scans the folders, gla over at Susan who is making some notes on a file of her o He motions to her to please come sit beside him, she chec that Drew is still busy in the cockpit, tucks her papers her carryall, and crosses over to Parrish who folds away work that Drew set before him into his tray table, locks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were in a meeting--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  With you. He peers up ahead at Drew, on the telephone and gesticula ing intensely, right at home in the cockpit despite the C of the blades and the pilot pressed up against him. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love Drew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...There's a start for a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's none of my business -- Susan doesn't answer for a moment, then impulsively kisse father on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's none of your business. Another moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love Drew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like you loved Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about me and Mom -- are you going to marry him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get carried away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh oh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, you're a hell of a woman. You've got a great career, you're beautiful --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm your daughter and no man will ever be good enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn't going to say that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you going to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm crazy about the guy -- He's smart, he's aggressive, he could carry Parrish Communications into the 21st century and me along with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for me.  I'm talking about you.  It's not so much what you say about Drew, it's what you don't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not listening --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I am.  Not an ounce of excitement, not a whisper of a thrill, this relationship has all the passion of a pair of titmice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get dirty, Dad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it worries me.  I want you to get swept away.  I want you to levitate.  I want you to sing with rapture and dance like a dervish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be deliriously happy.  Or at least leave yourself open to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Be deliriously happy'.  I'm going to do my upmost -- He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's a cornball thing but love is passion, obsession, someone you can't live without.  If you don't start with that, what are you going to end up with?  I say fall head over heels.  Find someone you can love like crazy and who'll love you the same way back.  And how do you find him?  Forget your head and listen to your heart.  I'm not hearing any heart. (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run the risk, if you get hurt, you'll come back.  Because, the truth is there is no sense living your life without this.  To make the journey and not fall deeply in love -- well, you haven't lived a life at all. You have to try.  Because if you haven't tried, you haven't lived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, you're tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  But give it to me again. The short version.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay open.  Who knows?  Lightning could strike. Silence. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive the lecture --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.  And when I tell Drew about it, he won't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't tell him, and even if you did, he'd clock it and punch it into his laptop in order to pull out some key phrases when he gives the Commencement Speech at Wharton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  But I'm the only father you've got. She kisses him on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't care.  But thanks anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AStar lands, an attendant, waiting with a luggage car rushes to open the door and unload the bags.  The passeng Parrish paired with Quince, Drew with Susan, file off the rooftop through a door which opens into an elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish, Susan, Drew and Quince face forward as they ride downwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is it, the hour approach- es, I'm getting all excited.  So what do you think, is it -- (indicates Drew and Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- just the 'Executive Committee' or could you guys use me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quince, m'man, thanks for the offer, but it's all set for just me and Bill. More people might --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Gum up the works. Parrish is about to make some reassuring comment to Quinc when the Voice suddenly intrudes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '...I know, it's none of my business.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was saying to Quince we won't need --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you just hear something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why yes, Bill, I was saying to Quince --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  I'm sorry. A respectful silence, the elevator continues downwards, suddenly the Voice intrudes again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '...I want you to levitate.  I want you to sing with rapture and dance like a dervish.' Parrish grunts bizarrely, Susan notices and reacts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Daddy --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Parrish's eyes dart about, confirming no one has heard a thing but him. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just talking to myself again.  You know me -- The elevator door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here we are -- Parrish leads the group out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A-Okay.  Got my gloves on, my ears pricked.  I'm ready for action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, go get 'em, Pops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer damn right. Parrish, followed by Drew, steps into a waiting limousine Quince looks longingly after them.  Susan, blowing a kiss goodbye to her father, steps out into the street to hustl cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Tomorrow we sign off -- photo opportunity, you and Big John, it'll lead network news.  Okay so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be great --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I need a haircut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, after this deal, you'll be able to afford one. Parrish smiles, they step into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish and Drew emerge from the elevator, Parrish observ the overkill decor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their PR guy asked me, what did I think Parrish Communications stood for, that's principle and ethics- wise?  I came up with something, but then it occurred to me, why don't I ask Bill?  What do you think? A moment, Parrish shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our first annual report, must be thirty-five years ago now, I owned two stations, I wrote down a state- ment of purpose, that one day you would wake up to a Parrish radio station, read a Parrish paper at breakfast, catch our news on tele- vision during the day, and go to bed with one of our books or magazines and you would always be told the truth and in the bargain, have a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great!  Wait 'til I show it to Bontecou. Drew opens a door, a conference room, a circle of top exe utives, now stepping out from the group is a huge, white- haired man, JOHN BONTECOU, 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, thanks for coming over... (to Drew)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how're you doing today, Drew? (to Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got a firecracker here, the kid's really set the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good.  Glad to hear it. BONTECOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've met before, y'know, that White House function, the President had you on his right and you know where I was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't recall --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left field somewhere.  Well, Bill, I want to come in from the outfield, bat cleanup like you have, learn the plush ropes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were buying my company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Parrish, I could never buy Parrish Communications.  I could pay for it, of course, but it would always have your imprint. Silence.  Parrish looks around at the circle of 'suits', Bontecou holding away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's very nice to hear. Drew nods excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The busy medical community at 68th Street and New York Av

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thriving eatery diagonally across from the hospital's entrance, customers cheek-by-jowl as a pair of waiters juggle breakfasts served to a noisy throng of doctors, residents and interns. Susan has squeezed into a seat in the corner.  A counterm with a smile and a greeting, places a cup of coffee in fr of her.  A sense this is a daily ritual, arming herself f the day; immediately she becomes aware of a man behind he speaking into the pay phone. An attractive YOUNG MAN, early 30's, a pair of suitcase a his feet, a raincoat slung over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Honey, you've got to go on... there's a time to sow and a time to reap, you sow now and forget about him... yeah, I liked him, I don't like him anymore... because you're my honey and anybody messes with you messes with me -- I'm on a plane in a minute... as soon as I get my phone in, you're my first call, that's a promise... where you going now?... good, hit the books, get that degree, one day we'll hang out a shingle together... you bet, honey... later. The Young Man hangs up, turns around and sits down to an overflowing plate of eggs and meat, potatoes and toast, t counterman refills his cup and the Young Man ties into th breakfast, eating it with such relish that Susan can't ta her eyes off him.  He senses her eyes, glances over, his cheeks filled with a mouthful of food, swallows embarrass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, I was talking kind of loud there, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.  It was fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?  What was 'fascinating' about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and 'Honey'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My kid sister.  She just broke up with her boyfriend and she's thinking about dropping out of law school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to be sorry about.  That's the way with men and women, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing lasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just being agreeable, now I've got to explain why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to sharpshoot you, but that 'nothing lasts' stuff, that's what was the trouble with Honey's guy.  He was fooling around and Honey caught him at it.  One girlfriend wasn't enough for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're a one-girl guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right.  Looking for her right now.  Who knows?  You might be her. Susan laughs. YOUNG MAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't laugh.  I just arrived in town, got a new job -- I'm trying to get into this apartment.  You a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody's a doctor around here. This apartment house is all green pajamas and slippers.  The guy I'm waiting for to vacate is a doctor. What kind of doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?  Internal medicine. The Young Man smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if I needed a doctor, you could be it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could be her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Her'. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I could. (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an office in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- This is my lucky day.  I arrive in this big bad city and I not only find a doctor, a beautiful woman as well. Susan looks into her coffee. YOUNG MAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, you mind my saying that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout another cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got patients coming in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I want to get into my apartment and go to work.  Please, what do you say, another cup of coffee? Two pots are warming behind the counter, he reaches over refills her cup and his.  Pushes a container and pitcher wards her. YOUNG MAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you use lots of sugar and cream.  Me, too... They smile at each other, fix up their coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magnificent granite building, a monument to good taste the midtown sea of glass and aluminum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish and Drew enter, no particular fanfare but an awar ness the 'Chief' has arrived, everyone giving Parrish the appropriate wide berth, Drew right beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all excited --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was great, I thought you and Big John would be like a couple of bulls in a china shop -- (faltering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead it was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a marriage made in heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a way with words. They stride to the main bank of elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish, Drew beside him, proceeds through a high tech, b tasteful, maze, spiffy executive secretaries at burnished desks.  Neither looking right or left, somehow Parrish ma ages to acknowledge their bright smiles and deferential n despite his swift entrance. He passes through an open set of doors and he is into his own suite, commanded by JENNIFER, his assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Parrish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jennifer. Drew is still at Parrish's heels, but now Parrish stops a the open door, turns back to him, reminding Drew that thi is as far as he goes without being invited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... Board convenes tomorrow, you'll recommend, we close and it's a deal, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As close as a deal could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bursting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olympic. Parrish disappears into his office.  Drew, on his way out glides past Jennifer's desk. DREW (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our lucky day. Jennifer acknowledges Drew with a smile, rises and moves Parrish's doorway, waiting for the day's instructions, bu Parrish only nods to the door and Jennifer quickly closes it, returns to her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in his office, Parrish's ebullient mood immediately changes.  Leaning against the back of the couch, he stare out through floor-to-ceiling windows, surveying the Manhattan skyline: cogitates. He takes a seat on the couch, opens a folder, suddenly he flinches with a spasm of pain in his shoulder.  It is sha but brief, he notices it but what it does not continue, h ignores it. Parrish resumes looking at the folder when suddenly the pain comes again.  He reaches for his shoulder, tries to massage the pain, it does not subside.  Parrish stands, trying to shake it off, but it refuses to go away, some- thing is unmistakably wrong.  Now a SOUND which he has come to recognize, makes itself heard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Frozen with surprise, Parrish's eyes search the room for source of the SOUND, it comes from no particular directio yet surrounds him.  Suddenly Parrish's symptoms sharply intensify, he is sinking to the floor but somehow grabs a corner of the desk, holds on with one hand, with the othe clutches at his shoulder and arm, the pain has violently seized the upper part of his body.  He breaks out in a sw his pallor now waxen as the Voice repeats itself: VOICE (V.O., cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yes. Parrish grips the edge of the desk, the pain assaulting h on the one hand, the Voice coming at him from the outer, each aberration feeds on the other, he is beside himself, consumed with pain and bewildered by what seems to be a hallucination but which he is certain is not.  Parrish is possessed.  He angles his face in every direction, arbi- trarily chooses one and now embarrassedly, unconsciously, enrage, responds to the Voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Yes' what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Yes' is the answer to your question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't ask any question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you did. Parrish is absolutely confounded, seized up with pain and consternation at this unseen Voice which has such presenc and reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Silence. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit, what is going on?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try.  Because 'if you haven't tried, you haven't lived'. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you were talking about. Parrish gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?  Who is this fucking guy? He holds on tight to the corner of the desk, sweat drippi his skin ashen.  Now he addresses the Voice again, search for it in another direction: PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me who you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you giving me orders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not.  You're trying to 'handle' the situation but this is the one situation you knew you never could handle. A spasm, the worst one yet, finally it subsides and there an eerie silence in the room, a VOID, almost more disturb than the voice that has filled it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?  Are you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's enough now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  Talk to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's going to be plenty of time for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what? (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what, goddammit! The VOICE is gone.  Parrish searches the corner, but the room has lost the quality it had when it was inhabited by the VOICE, it is now just Parrish's office.  Faint SQUEAL traffic from the street, then a KNOCK at the door. Parrish touches his shoulder, the pain is gone, but he is still wet with sweat, the KNOCK again.  Parrish straighte himself up, adjusts his tie, runs his fingers through his hair, blinks as he addresses the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. Jennifer enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been buzzing you, Mr. Parrish. Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch is 'in' today, have you given it any thought --_

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing? Parrish is within himself, doesn't answer. JENIFER (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't I think of something? Parrish still doesn't answer, however Jennifer is satisfi correctly hearing his silence as an affirmative.  She has hand on the door, 'Open' or 'Closed'?  He nods and she cl Utter silence again.  Parrish's eyes search the room, not there.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORINTH COFFEE SHOP, YORK AVENUE, DAY
dialogues.text: The place has cleared out now, the counterman busy bussin tables laden with dishes and cups, Susan and the Young Ma are still at the counter, but about to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's kind of a pro bono job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Pro bono'.  That means doing good -- Going to be doing good all your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what you're saying.  Doesn't pay very well.  Depends on the woman I marry.  Maybe she'd like a bigger house, a better car, lotsa kids, college doesn't come cheap --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd give up what you want for the woman you marry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would. Susan rises now, the Young Man with her, leaving money fo their checks they head for the door. YOUNG MAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I married you, I'd want to give you what you wanted, I know it's old fashioned and all that, but what's wrong with taking care of a woman?  She takes care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have a hard time finding a woman like that these days --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know.  Lightning could strike. Susan at the door now, pauses abruptly, her eyes on the Young Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Man holds the door for Susan as they step out onto the street. Susan is staring at him now, he smiles, all open and vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I say something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was so right it scares me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking... I don't want you to be my doctor.  Because I don't want you to examine me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I like you so much. (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have coffee here every morning, don't you?  If I came by, could you give me the name of a doctor? Another moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I'll give you the name of a doctor. (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And I don't want to examine you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I like you so much.  Now I've got to go. She hurries away down the sidewalk, the Young Man watchin her.  Now he turns and starts off in the opposite directi

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She looks back at the Young Man, then turns and walks on.

dialogues.speaker: THE YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: He looks back at Susan as the distance between them widen now he turns and walks on.

dialogues.speaker: ON SUSAN
dialogues.text: She looks around once more but the Young Man is still hea in the opposite direction, his back to her.  She turns th corner and continues on.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Approaching the corner, he looks back for Susan yet again but she is gone, still turned he steps off into the stree and a hospital supplies truck, speeding down the curb lan HITS HIM BROADSIDE, a horrific impact, the THUD echoes as his body arcs through the air. Another sickening THUD as it lands, the Young Man lies crumpled, still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful space adjacent to the dining room, it has a glass roof which offers a superb view of the Manhattan sk line.  The hour is before dinner: gathered on one side of the room are Allison and Parrish, on the other side Drew Quince.  COYLE, a butler, and LUISA, the housekeeper, pas hors d'oeuvres and drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Music, I know how you love music, Daddy, and I want to have music that pleases you -- and of course doesn't put a thousand other people to sleep -- I've agonized over this and finally settled on Sidney Brown, twenty-four men, very eclectic, plus I'm feathering in a Latin sextet on their breaks - Tito Puente, Trini Lopez-zy, I forget their names -- Parrish has tuned Allison out, he tried to stay with it, his mind has wandered, the event of the day too much with him. ALLISON (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't heard a word, have you? I keep talking and all you do is nod like Mr. Himmelfass in The Nutcracker. Parrish still doesn't answer. ALLISON (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't care, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lay awake nights in a cold sweat, I want this party to be like some- thing Mom would have made for you, I want it to be perfect --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (attentive now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you do, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you could care less --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you couldn't be more wrong, sweetheart.  I can' tell you how much I appreciate it and how I'm looking forward to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Songs.  What songs should Sidney -- Pancho and his six men we can forget about -- what songs do you think he should play? A stab of pain, Parrish discreetly grabs his upper arm bu manages to keep his attention on Allison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell it to me again. Suddenly, the Voice cuts in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Yes. Parrish's head snaps, startled by the SOUND. VOICE (V.O., cont'd) (to Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you miss me? Parrish reacts once more, aware again he is the only one has heard the Voice, as an oblivious Allison continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.  Leave it to me. Parrish ignores her, his attention has been taken by the Voice.  His eyelids flutter, nonplused, edgy and fearful. LUISA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Parrish, dinner is served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Quince and Drew, across the room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chow-time, you guys. Parrish is confounded.  Blindly and disconcerted, he foll Allison and Drew and Quince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a disturbed Parrish approaches the table, he hears the Voice once more:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking so provoked about?  'Did you miss me?'  It's a normal question.  I missed you. But what do I get back?  'Not an ounce of excitement, not a whisper of a thrill --' Parrish sits. VOICE (V.O., cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '-- This relationship has all the passion of a pair of titmice'. Parrish is on the edge of his seat, struggling to hide hi panic. VOICE (V.O., cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting outside. The conversation swirls on around Parrish, he is deaf to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Drew)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you speak to the Governor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately.  I sat between them at the Bronx Zoo benefit -- it was better than Seconal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting outside.  Won't someone come to the door? Parrish is in shock, still striving to gain control of himself.  As Coyle serves him, Parrish turns to Luisa:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is somebody waiting outside, Luisa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear a ring, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please have a look -- Luisa goes as Coyle continues serving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Quince)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Mayor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he would be there with bells on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, maybe they'll drown him out. Parrish is still not hearing a word, preoccupied with the return of Luisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't be negative, Drew, we have an acceptance list that would do The White House proud -- The Secretary-General of the UN, the Chairman of the FCC, nine Senators, I don't know how many Congressmen, and at least twelve of the Fortune '500'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No jocks?  A twenty-game winner or a Masters champion?  Someone I could talk to. (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or would talk to me. Luisa returns to Parrish as the others' conversation dron on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Mr. Parrish.  There was a gentleman at the door.  He's waiting for you in the foyer. Parrish is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show him into the library, tell him I'll be right there. Parrish, spinning with anxiety, tries to summon up his co to go as Allison continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've arranged for favors -- silver charm bracelets for the women, platinum keychains for the men -- all engraved 'W.P.' -- but now I'm thinking of scrubbing them, they seem so ordinary. Finally Parrish rises from the table, starts out. ALLISON (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they ordinary?  Do they seem that way to you, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- I don't know.  No - uh - I don't... Allison is about to press the point, but then drifts into disappointed silence as Parrish leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're overthinking it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think they're ordinary.  I love keychains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish moves deliberately down the hall, slows as he nea the doorway to the library.  The door is open.  He hesita before he crosses the threshold, taking in as much as his eye can see, now tentatively, he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful, classic room, areas of dim, warm light, club chairs, books reaching to the ceiling, a rolling library ladder, a weathered dictionary on a stand, a model boat carved of bone set into the stacks which are separated fr the reading area by a seven-foot high partition of obscur glass. Parrish, poised in the doorway, looks around, nothing in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Silence. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone here? No response. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said is anyone here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet down. Parrish is startled, he shrinks backward for a moment, hi eyes searching the room for the Voice, the timbre and pit of which is exactly what he has heard before.  There is t sense that someone is there but Parrish cannot see him, a he does not dare look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. Now a flicker of a shadow from behind a corner of the obs glass, the section of the room most distant from Parrish, there is a shape.  Something is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, a joke, right?  Some kind of elaborate practical joke? At my 40th reunion, we delivered a casket to the Class president's hotel room and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. Parrish falls silent, something in the SOUND and TONE of Voice muting him.  He takes a step backwards. VOICE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I - I - uh -- The shape moves, makes itself more visible.  Although sti diffused by the glass, the shape has definition, a person man, his features are not yet distinguishable, but he is there all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great Bill Parrish at a loss for words?  The man from whose lips fall 'rapture' and 'passion' and 'obses- sion'...all those admonitions about being 'deliberately happy', what there is no sense 'living your life without...', all the sparks and energy you give off, the rosy advice you dispense in round, pear-shaped tones --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think of millenniums multiplied by aeons compounded by infinity, I've been around that long, but it's only recently that your affairs here have piqued my interest.  Call it boredom, the natural curiosity of me, the most lasting and significant element in existence has come to see you. Parrish struggles to make sense of what he is hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to have a look around before I take you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Take me'...?  Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It requires competence, wisdom, experience -- all those things they say about you in testimonials -- and you're the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The one' to do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me around.  Be my guide.  And in return, you get...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In return you'll receive minuets, days, weeks, I'm not going to go into details ... what matters is that I stay interested. Parrish squints, trying to make sense of what is happenin VOICE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Yes' is the answer to your ques- tion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill.  Come on.  The question.  The question you've been asking yourself with increased regularity, at odd moments, panting through the extra game of handball, when you ran for the plane in Delhi, when you sat up in bed last night and hit the floor in the office this morning.  The question that is in the back of your throat, choking the blood to your brain, ringing in the ears over and over as you put it to yourself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'question' --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Bill.  The question. After a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Am I going to die? The figure who is the Voice takes a step forward now, no longer obscured by the glass he comes into the light, re- vealing himself to be the Young Man seen previously in th coffee shop, but there is a change; he seems odd, off- center, not handsome but terrifyingly beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. A moment, Parrish beside himself.  He cannot bring himsel to speak, finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I dreaming this? (Another moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're coming to 'take me'.  What is that?  Who the hell are you? The Young Man steps closer to Parrish, his face is inches from a shaking, sweating Parrish's face, the Young Man daring Parrish to identify him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urging again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '...Yes --' Parrish turns away.  But the Young Man, spectacularly, is front of him again. YOUNG MAN (cont'd) (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Death. Parrish is shocked, stunned, terrified at the word, by wh he has comprehended.  He surveys the Young Man who, at th moment, actually seems bewildered by his effect. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not Death.  You're just a kid in a jacket and a pair of pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jacket and the pair of pants came with the body I took.  Let me ask your opinion.  Do I blend in? A hopelessly confused Parrish does not respond for a mome

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to be your guide --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fill the bill, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do? (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will you be staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should hope quite a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then --? The Young Man nods, gently. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... it's... over. A long silence.  Parrish and the Young Man take each othe the sense that now they understand each other.  A SOUND a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Parrish? Parrish does not hear her for the moment, Luisa steps ins the Library. LUISA (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will the gentleman be staying for dinner, sir? Parrish ignores her at first, finally he looks at Luisa t at the Young Man, then once more at both of them as if to verify the Young Man's presence has been acknowledged by Luisa.  The Young Man interjects:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luisa)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (a polite afterthought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Luisa nods perfunctorily and exits.  Parrish is frozen, dumbfounded. YOUNG MAN (cont'd) (to Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is dinner? Parrish does not answer at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy -- you're not going to eat dinner with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill, I am eating dinner with you. And your family.  And that's what we're doing.  It's not open for discussion.  Nothing is.  Don't you understand? Parrish is frightened by the response. YOUNG MAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Now lead the way. Parrish hesitates, then obediently leads the Young Man ou of the library, down a long hallway and across the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?  Could I say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just occurred to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speak up, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I introduce you, if I say who you are, I don't think anyone will stay for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Parrish and the Young Man enter, Allison is heard in t background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, here's another possibility. It's a little last minute, but how does this strike you?  Kaleidoscopes. Little gold kaleidoscopes.  Some German firm went kerplunkt, Tiffany's picked these things up, they're perfect party favors, however they're not personal, they're winter scene or something, snow-flakes and dachshunds... Parrish and the Young Man appear at the table, an awkward pause ensues, the unannounced guest's presence at a famil dinner being noted, and the guest himself carefully surve ed.  Finally, Allison breaks the ice: ALLISON (cont'd) (to the Young Man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Parrish is horribly uncomfortable as the Young Man looks each person as if he were discovering a face of the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- sorry -- to have stepped away for so long -- uh -- this is a friend of mine I asked to drop by -- we got to talking and stuff -- uh -- he's going to join us for dinner -- um -- Parrish drifts into another awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Young Man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, how nice to meet you.  And wouldn't it be nicer if my father would introduce you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Allison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '...How nice to meet you.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry.  This is my daughter, Allison, and her husband, Quince, Drew, my number one, works with me... Parrish drifts off as the Young Man awkwardly shakes hand with each person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (prompting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy.  Does your friend have a name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly, going along with the joke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, something he goes by --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, excuse me.  This is -- uh -- this is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy!  Come on, a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Bill, the suspense is killing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry...um - you - you know it's gone right out of my head --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  This is - uh - uh... The group waits patiently. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe... Parrish once more drifts into silence.  (The YOUNG MAN is identified as "JOE".)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just plain 'Joe'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love that name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.  Hey, buddy! Joe, turned on by Quince's broad smile, reacts to it as D squints observingly at Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any more to it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like 'Smith' or 'Jones --' Parrish's face reveals a desperate searching for a last n a furtive glance at Joe.  Parrish's brow darkens and a na tumbles from his lips:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whew, at last.  Nice to meet you, Mr. Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Joe Black'.  Won fifteen and lost two for the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1952.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.  I'm kind of my Rotisserie League.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is!  Let's sit down -- Luisa has set a plate in front of Joe, and Parrish's, whi was taken to the kitchen to be warmed, has been returned. Joe looks over at the other guests, then picks up his ute sils gingerly, strives to copy the others, stops, staring his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paillarde of veal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they hit the calf over the head with a mallet and then Luisa hits it again in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey --!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm saying, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing emptily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe knows what you're saying, just being polite -- Drew is studying Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we met?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- he's from out of town --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you here, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as it takes. Drew is provoked by the response, but remains polite:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Bill old friends? Parrish jumps in:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get the feeling you've done some business before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an arrangement now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What side of the industry did you say you were on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe sounds like a ringer, Bill.  I have the feeling you guys got the broad strokes already.  Need any help with the details? Parrish falls silent again, looking for an answer. DREW (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- business at dinner... (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me for being so rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. The doors to the dining room open, Susan appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, everybody.  Sorry to be late - had to have dinner with my depart- ment chief --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm here, aren't I?  Wouldn't miss a loose end meeting.  What's on the table for discussion?  Party favors, flowers -- hi Dad, hi Drew -- She kisses Drew in some light, humorous way they have ob- viously done before, their heads bobbing like plastic wat toys and their lips meeting mid-air. At the kiss's conclusion Susan suddenly notices Joe is present and has been watching.  She is shocked, embarrass pleased, conflicted, an instant and wide spectrum of emot SUSAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- This morning.  The Corinth Coffee Shop.  He was looking for a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess he's found one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, you do get around. Joe is happily confounded by all the interaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And isn't it a lovely one?  So sturdy, so straight -- Joe has heard Susan's question but, as he studies her, doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incidentally, Joe, where're you staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Here'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! Parrish pushes his plate away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh - will that hold you, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incidentally, 'Joe' what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what are you doing here? Parrish tenses, but Joe doesn't answer. SUSAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cat got your tongue?  You weren't so silent this morning. Drew reacts to this allusion of intimacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm getting interested.  I want to know more ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got some things to discuss. Parrish stands, motions for Joe to rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Did I hear 'business'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What 'business'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother asking, we already tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so very nice to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, I don't get that feeling. Maybe it's because you found out I'm Bill Parrish's daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Susan. (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and I've got to talk.  Big day tomorrow, everybody.  Joe, let's go. Joe rises, follows Parrish to the door, stops:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Susan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. (to Allison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allison. (to Quince)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quince. (to Drew)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew. (to Parrish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill... (to the group)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He makes an awkward little bow, then heads for the neares door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe, that's the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Joe pivots, and he follows Parrish out the proper door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was 'Joe'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very. Susan's eyes are still on the door where Joe exited, her face reflecting her irritation and bewilderment, as well a tinge of excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish leads the way, Joe beside him as they progress th the huge house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sorry, I'm a little discon- certed, that stuff between you and Susan -- uh -- threw me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Threw' you?  Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shook me up.  I mean that you knew her and everything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know her.  The body I took knew her.  The man she met in the coffee shop this morning.  I - uh - took him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there's nothing between you and Susan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you had said something to me about staying here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hadn't occurred to me until then. I was just having such a wonderful time -- Besides, isn't this what I'm here for? Parrish suddenly looks very anxious, Joe stops. JOE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem uncomfortable, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm okay with this - uh - I think.  So -- He opens a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Joe)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathroom...tub...towels, sauna -- Parrish turns back to the bedroom. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Chair, lamp, bed -- Parrish is in a stunned state, chatters on unconsciously: PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Box springs, they're assembled in Jakarta.  Had to stay in a station manager's house there unexpectedly - best night's sleep I ever had. Ordered twenty, they filled a con- tainer and shipped them right over, I've put one in every bedroom here and in the country. Joe tests the springs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Would you like the man's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Parrish glances around, a room in which the occupant coul not want for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there is anything else, don't hesitate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're putting me on the spot, Bill. A moment. JOE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's put it this way.  When I go, you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you go, I go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the best I can do. (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but minute-by-minute, I find myself lingering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I just saw my doctor, he told me everything was fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your doctor? (icily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your doctor say anything about a tiny, undetectable hole in your aorta?  Did he mention an irreparab- ly weak vein in the further reaches of your famous brain?  Were they any prognostications about the possibil- ilites of a fatal collision on a golf cart of suffocating in an avalanche on a skin vacation in Gstaad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you realize, Bill...in your office this morning, that was your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer than that. Parrish keeps still, trying to cool the heat of Joe's temper. JOE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But meanwhile, you are still here.  Count your blessings.  Call it gravy, frosting on the cake, whatever it is you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you for letting me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And - uh - I  guess, 'goodnight'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night to you, Bill. Parrish gently closes the door. Joe looks around, checks out his surroundings: curious, attentive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish, unsteady, starts back down the hall, Luisa appea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Miss Allison asked if you would like to have your dinner kept warm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thanks, Luisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, sir. Luisa turns:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luisa -- She stops. PARRISH (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Black's luggage was misplaced by the airlines.  Would you mind get- ting a few things together for him? A couple of suits, some shirts, ties, underwear, shoes.  Have Coyle take his measurements off what he is wearing tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, sir. Luisa nods, and heads back downstairs.  Parrish enters his den, takes a seat in his chair, stares into the middl distance, ruminates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe has been examining his room, full of curiosity and wonderment at the oddest things, the handle on a casement window, the hem and weight of the fabric of a drape, hing on the bedroom door.  In the process he opens this door, steps out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe wanders down the hallway past the occasional Dufy or Miro, a Venetian tapestry cheek-by-jowl with a miniature Ming vae, and even a Bonsai garden with a trickling vein of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the "back" of the house now, utilitarian paint and dec the SOUND of laughter and a glare of light.  Joe enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff is at ease, some smoking, remains of food aroun Coyle, the butler, has his back to Joe and does not see h for a moment.  In front of Coyle, an open jar of peanut b ter which he is spreading in generous hunks of Wonder Bre Joe is fascinated by the process.  Coyle suddenly hears t silence, looks up and see Joe, standing up embarrassedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  I'm Joe Black.  Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, Mr. Black, a pleasure. The staff all mumble expansive "Good evening, sir"s to Jo He motions to them to sit, they do but Coyle does not.  C shifts from foot-to-foot, the staff is not used to having Parrish family or guests in this part of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Coyle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean this, sir? Coyle regards his peanut butter sheepishly. COYLE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura Scudder's Peanut Butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Laura Scudder's Peanut Butter'. (a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would say, sir, it is right up there with Jif and Skippy.  But miles ahead of Peter Pan. (another moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a taste? Joe nods, Coyle fashions a spoonful, offers it to Joe.  J swallows it.  But he has not yet found a comfortable way masticating, his mouth and tongue go every which way, the staff observes him, fascinated. COYLE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a peanut butter man now, eh, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.  I thoroughly enjoyed this - uh - peanut butter. (to the staff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I thoroughly enjoyed meeting you. Joe raises the spoonful of peanut butter in a kind of toa to the staff. JOE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be moseying on. He heads out, with the spoonful of peanut butter, to chee ful "Goodnight, Mr. Black"'s, his tongue again licking th edges of the spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A spectacular indoor Olympic pool, window commanding view of the skyline. Susan is swimming laps, looking very professional in a bl Speedo suit, Joe wanders in, still licking his peanut but He observes her, but she is unaware of him, however now, she makes a barrel turn, his shadow falls over a reflecti from a window, she aborts her lap, looks up to see who it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Can't seem to escape you today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Susan climbs out of the pool, gets halfway up the ladder, points to a stack of towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hand me one of those, will you? Joe turns to the towels, but one hand is occupied with th spoonful of peanut butter, he shifts it to the other hand can't manage the huge Turkish towel one-handed, now impla the spoon in his mouth, lifts the towel with both hands a presents it to Susan. SUSAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must have something really big going on with my father --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Big'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You appear at his side out-of-the- blue, stay at his house, eat dinner with his family, it's practically a first.  You're in the red-hot center of big business and I thought you were a regular Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the one I met this morning, hit- ting on me in as nice a way as I've been hit on in a long time, but the moment you find out I'm my Dad's daughter, you act like a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not my intention. Joe continues to nibble at his peanut butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your intentions?  To make little dreams in coffee shops, turn a woman's head, and I don't mind admitting it was turned, I liked it, but ten hours later I feel like a fool.  I don't get it.  You, my father, here in this house, the cof- fee shop, it's making me upset, and I don't like being upset.  Who are you anyway?  And what are you eating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peanut butter. He finishes the spoonful. JOE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's gone now. He shifts the spoon from hand to hand, starts to stick it his pocket, realizes this is inappropriate.  Susan holds hand out to him, he places the spoon in it and she sets t spoon on the table with the towels.  She watches, fascina ed, as Joe licks his gums, enjoying every last bit of his spoonful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You act like you never had peanut butter before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- What kind of childhood did you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love Drew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you put your mouth to his, Susan, it seems a frequent thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew is none of your damn business. Nor is where I put my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  Do you live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Joe, I'm swimming here.  Then I'm going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess what I'm trying to say is -- I'd like us to be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got plenty of friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see why. She finishes drying herself, drops the towel on a chair, prepares to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I didn't mean to offend you at dinner.  I'm not quite at home some- times with people.  I get busy doing - uh - what I do, and I don't seem to have developed -- He drifts off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a certain function to per- form, and that seems to take all of my time.  Bu sometimes - uh - I speculate - uh - I haven't left room for - uh - anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to say I know what you're saying. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know you have a wet spot on your shoulder? She glances at her shoulder, he grabs a towel, touches th drops of water, pats them dry, hands her the towel.  She flashes a nervous smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight to you, Susan. Susan steps towards a door, Joe takes a step in the wrong direction, they almost walk into each other.  Now she tak a step in another direction, as does Joe, again they almo collide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we dance? Joe is completely puzzled, finally Susan heads for one do Joe for another. SUSAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you want to go to the west wing.  Through there. Susan indicates yet another door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Joe redirects himself, goes to the door.  As they both ar about to exit, Joe and Susan sneak furtive looks at each other across the pool, smile at catching each other's glances.  Joe exits.  For a moment Susan's eyes remain on the door through which he has gone.  Now she grips the to over her shoulders, the one Joe gave her, pats the same s he did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish, dressed for the day, passes servants busy with their morning tasks, polishing doorknobs, putting away linen, dusting picture frames.  He nods and greets them a he strides down the hall, brisk "Good morning"'s to Coyle and Luisa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parrish knocks, waits a courteous moment, opens the door, finds Joe in an elegant shirt and trousers trying to tie tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you?  How're you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Feeling'?  I feel fine.  How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um -- well, I didn't sleep too well. This is crazy.  This is the left- field thing of all time.  What do I do?  What do I tell my family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
